In terms of overpotentials, those are related to to the activity and so there's multiple overpotentials for what activity you want to get. At least in the field of homogeneous electrocatalysis, I think there these things are a little bit more worked out in terms of their Tafel relationships and extracting rate constants for a for a process or a maximum turnover frequency. And in principle you can relate that back then to activation energies if you if you take into account the Eyring relationship.

Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.explanation: Gary provides detailed factual information about the complexities of heterogeneous catalysis and contrasts it with the more established methods in homogeneous electrocatalysis, using specific technical terms like Tafel relationships and Eyring relationship.
Knowledge Contribution & Expertise Signa.score_justification: The speaker provides highly relevant and concrete technical details about the challenges in heterogeneous catalysis and the more developed methods in homogeneous catalysis, including specific relationships and concepts.

utterance: Rebecca Gieseking: So not that specific spectroscopy. I've done a lot of modeling related to surface-enhanced Raman where you have the plasmonic type enhancement. From the computational side, I don't see that as necessarily being a problem because if we have somewhere where we can validate our methods and figure out what features do need to be included and don't need to be included, even if it's not the best catalyst, then that's still really valuable for us.

utterance: Carlos Morales-Guio Guio: It's a challenge. I mean, because we we can measure product distributions and then when we know that many of the cells that we use for spectroscopy actually they do not have the same mass transport properties. So it's challenging but I see obviously people working on this efforts and yeah, it's a challenge.
